• Normal range: 18–24°C
• Above 25°C: Uncomfortable heat
• Above 30°C: Heat stress risk
• Below 10°C: Cold stress risk

Optimal indoor temperature is 20–22°C.

• Inhalable particles (≤10μm diameter)
• Safe level: <50 μg/m³ (24h avg)
• EU limit: 50 μg/m³
• WHO guideline: 45 μg/m³ (annual)

Can cause respiratory issues when elevated.

• Fine inhalable particles (≤2.5μm)
• Safe level: <25 μg/m³ (24h avg)
• WHO guideline: 15 μg/m³ (annual)

Penetrates deep into lungs and bloodstream. Long-term exposure increases cardiovascular risks.

• Gas from combustion processes
• Safe level: <40 μg/m³ (annual)
• WHO guideline: 25 μg/m³ (24h)

Causes airway inflammation and reduces lung function. Major component of smog.

• Ground-level ozone (pollutant)
• Safe level: <100 μg/m³ (8h avg)
• WHO guideline: 60 μg/m³ (8h)

Causes respiratory irritation. High levels worsen asthma and lung diseases.

• Comfortable range: 30–60%
• Below 30%: Dry air, irritation
• Above 60%: Mold growth risk

Optimal indoor humidity is 40–50% for health and comfort.

• Normal range: 970–1040 hPa
• Affects weather patterns
• Low pressure: Often brings storms
• High pressure: Usually clear skies

Rapid changes may affect sensitive individuals.

• Safe level: <55 dB (daytime)
• 55–65 dB: Stress effects
• Above 65 dB: Health risk
• WHO guideline: 53 dB (day)

Chronic noise exposure increases cardiovascular disease risk.
